title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for additional information. The Securities Act of 1933 mandates registration of securities with the SEC before public offering. The registration statement includes a prospectus with essential details like underwriters, business type, shareholders, debt, assets, and legal opinions. Regulations by the commission provide further registration process details. The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before public offering, with the prospectus containing essential details. Regulations provide further details on the registration process. Exempted transactions include private placements and intrastate offerings, while exempted securities include government securities and bank securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 covers various areas, including ongoing disclosure to investors. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires issuers with securities traded on a national exchange or with total assets exceeding $10,000,000 and a certain number of shareholders to register with the SEC and file periodic reports. Under the 1934 Act, issuers must register with the SEC and file periodic reports containing material information for investors. Sections 12 and 13 outline detailed statements and annual/quarterly reports requirements. Section 14 covers proxy solicitation, with some exemptions available. The SEC has issued regulations to enforce these reporting requirements. The Securities Exchange Act requires companies to register with the SEC and provide detailed reports to investors. Section 14 addresses proxy solicitation and exemptions. The SEC has regulations to ensure compliance. Failure to disclose material information can lead to legal action under Section 18(a) and Rule 10b-5. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires investment companies to register with the SEC and provide specified information to protect investors. Failure to comply with the act can result in legal action for omissions, misrepresentations, or manipulations of material facts. The Investment Company Act of 1940 mandates registration with the SEC and filing of specified information. Compliance is necessary for participation in securities activities. Restrictions are placed on affiliations and interests of directors, officers, and employees. Investment companies must adhere to reporting and financial statement requirements. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as someone who advises on securities' value for compensation. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as someone who advises on securities' value for compensation and must be registered with the SEC. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 was enacted to prevent insider trading. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 was enacted to prevent insider trading by increasing sanctions and deterrence against trading with material information not available to the public. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 expanded civil penalties for insider trading, allowing the commission to seek a civil penalty up to three times the profit gained or loss avoided. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 (P.L. 100-704) expanded civil penalties for insider trading, increased jail terms and fines for securities law violations, initiated a bounty program for informants, and required broker-dealers to establish policies to prevent misuse of inside information. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 addressed frivolous securities lawsuits. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 aimed to prevent frivolous shareholder lawsuits by addressing issues like fraud and mismanagement that led to shareholder losses. Some lawsuits were legitimate due to corporate managers misleading investors, while others were considered frivolous when stock value decreased for unrelated reasons. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 limits shareholder lawsuits in federal courts by appointing a lead plaintiff, restricting individuals from being lead plaintiffs in multiple class actions, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, providing a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, implementing proportionate liability, and including provisions for auditors. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to address perceived failures of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) in curbing securities fraud litigation abuses. SLUSA aimed to prevent plaintiffs from circumventing PSLRA by bringing cases in state courts based on non-federal claims, ensuring full disclosure of settlement terms, a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, proportionate liability, and auditor disclosure of corporate fraud. SLUSA aimed to prevent plaintiffs from avoiding PSLRA requirements by allowing securities fraud cases only in federal court under specific criteria, including being a covered class action, based on state law, involving a covered security, alleging misrepresentation, and related to the purchase or sale of a covered security. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was enacted in response to corporate scandals like Enron and WorldCom. It established a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and imposed restrictions on accounting firms providing services to audited companies. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 established the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board supervised by the SEC. It restricts accounting firms from providing certain services to audited companies and requires additional disclosures for public companies. Dodd-Frank, enacted in response to the financial crisis, addressed issues like securities fraud, management controls, penalties for violating securities laws, insider trading, and whistleblower protections. Dodd-Frank, passed in response to the financial downturn, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry. Title VII of Dodd-Frank regulates the over-the-counter swaps markets and outlines jurisdictional parameters for the CFTC and SEC. The title requires consultation between the CFTC and SEC when issuing regulations. Title IX of Dodd-Frank establishes new powers for the SEC, including the creation of an Office of the Investor Advocate and a whistleblower program for securities fraud disclosure. It also expands regulation of credit rating agencies and mandates public corporations to submit to certain requirements for investor protection. Title IX of Dodd-Frank includes provisions for investor protection, such as regulating credit rating agencies, requiring public corporations to disclose executive compensation, setting rules for proxy solicitation, and establishing a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. Additionally, it mandates disclosure of minerals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo benefiting armed groups. The STOCK Act prohibits insider trading by Members of Congress and employees, affirming a duty arising from a relationship of trust and confidence. The JOBS Act aims to facilitate funding for small businesses and startups by easing securities reporting requirements. Title I focuses on emerging growth companies with annual revenues under $1 billion, allowing them to gradually comply with SEC regulations. Title III addresses crowdfunding. Title III of the JOBS Act exempts certain companies from the 1933 Securities Act's registration requirements if specific conditions are met, such as limits on the amount of securities sold to investors. Investors can invest up to $100,000 in a 12-month period through a funding portal, based on their annual income or net worth.
